title: “My appearance may frighten you..."
body:
No, I am not frightened by the appearance of "Zero Suit Kerrigan".

Seriously, it's like the team behind her model and splash never even talked to the story team.

replies.body:
I feel Kai'Sa might just be like Quinn in terms of how underdeveloped she is on release, and I feel she may have been rushed along the development process. This is perhaps not the place to criticize her kit (though I personally think it's disjointed and full of generic mechanics), but her appearance, VO and even backstory feel similarly boring, and incongruous with what she's meant to be. What we all hoped for with Kassadin's daughter was to have a human experience the Void's corruption harder than any other, and come out visibly changed from it. What we got instead was a conventionally attractive young woman in a catsuit, with a generically friendly/bubbly female personality and a monotone voice. Many players have pointed out how she has no personality conveyed through her VO or story, particularly for someone whom everyone expected to have PTSD (which would be unique), but her appearance is probably the biggest contradiction: by intentional design, she looks sexy to the average player, with the skin-tight suit and heavy emphasis on cleavage, but one of her few defining characteristics is that she's meant to look monstrous to people in Runeterra. Perhaps the devs wanted to create a sexy female champion, but Kai'Sa really wasn't the right opportunity for it, at least not when we're constantly informed of how physically repulsive she's meant to be.

On that note: what exactly is the difference between Kaisa and Kai'Sa? Her backstory makes it seem like a big deal, but phonetically the two names are _exactly_ the same, so the entire idea of Void corruption there falls flat. If, at the end of the day, the biggest change the Void brought to Kai'Sa is that it made her mentally add an apostrophe when spelling her name, there's worse things one can suffer.

She knows what they call her-- how most people see her. In "The Girl Who Came Back" she points out that she has seen their fear 'scrawled across the mud walls' of villages... As far as her appearance, the way she moves, her hyper-fast R 'Killer Instinct' even her silhouette would instill fear in the people of Shurima, especially for people who, for the most part, have just second and third hand knowledge of Kai'Sa. Seems only fitting that her legend would grow, people would boast of their encounters with her, telling their own versions. Some true, some embellished, some outright lies. But it is young Illi who has first hand knowledge of who she is, what she wants. It's doubtful her parents would believe her, though. To them, Kai'Sa is the monster who almost killed their little girl, before they drove it back into the Void. Hope that answers some questions. GLHF.

I'm singularly impressed that you went this far through this comment nest to deliver such a detailed response. Thank you for putting this matter to rest.

This is perhaps something for another thread, but I have so many questions regarding Kai'Sa that I feel haven't yet been answered by her story: how come her body from the chest up is relatively conventional when the most common sign of Void corruption is a gruesome third eye? What unique qualities did little Kaisa have that allowed her to survive in a place where so many others have succumbed? How did she survive this ordeal alone without any apparent psychological dysfunction? Was there a character/personality concept for her where she was radically different from what she is now, and if so, what caused it to change?

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=xhxYw7Ta,comment-id=000000000000000000000000000000000000000000010000,timestamp=2018-03-05T18:24:02.955+0000)

What unique qualities did little Kaisa have that allowed her to survive in a place where so many others have succumbed? How did she survive this ordeal alone without any apparent psychological dysfunction? Was there a character/personality concept for her where she was radically different from what she is now, and if so, what caused it to change?

Those are all great questions. There will be a AMA later this week (Thursday) where the whole team can weigh in. As for her character/personality concept, we knew from the very beginning that we wanted a survivor, someone who never quit. But, in reality, even the most determined person can get vaporized in an instant if they didn't possess the skills to survive, or even if they do and just step in the wrong spot. She was raised in the deserts of Shurima and similar to indigenous tribes and cultures had a baseline set of survival skills that she learned. She used those to live day-by-day. But what separates Champions from the rest is the existence of the extraordinary. Like Newt in Aliens, Kai'Sa was able to survive in her new environment, but unlike Newt, she had a weapon and armor. As far as her PTSD, we wanted to show her now, not as she was three years in the Void, with no hope, abandonment issues, anger and loss of faith. She has a line in her VO, "Let go of the anger. It does not serve." In order to survive-- to get back, she only carried the things that would help her. She had worked out those issues during that time. It's important that she is who she is in game-- a hardened survivor and a hopeful ally in the fight against the Void. She should be messed up, angry, resentful and mercurial, but she's worked that out and she is an example of what can be. One of the cornerstones for me was reading about a certain survivor of a horrific trauma and her telling about how she deals with the memory and guilt and the nightmares. She said that it happened, but she wouldn't let it take any thing else from her. Not one more thing. She decided that was it. It sounded heroic and unimaginable for me to comprehend and that stuck with me. That is who Kai'Sa is. She is a Champion, although she wasn't always one, she became one.

I'm happy with her intent. She's a survivor, but you're showing us who she is after the struggle, not the struggle itself. Compared to Kassadin, Malzahar, and other characters, it's still hard to believe a ten year old child can overcome that. I think if either her bio, story, or comic reflected that more, it'd be easier to digest.

For example, even after MF got her revenge on GP, she still struggles, showing us how brutal Bilgewater can be.

Thank you for the response, and this does clear some things up.

With that said, I still personally have some difficulties with some parts of her presentation: I get that she was raised in Shurima, for example, and thus may have been better at surviving than, say, a Piltovian child, but at the same time there has been a Void entrance in Shurima for generations, yet she's the only one we know of to have survived that ordeal. When reading through her story, my one question to that was: why? Why did she survive where others did not? What made Kaisa, and Kaisa specifically, a survivor, when full-grown, adult Shurimans didn't make it?

This is also why I personally am hungry for more exposition with regards to how she dealt with her trauma: it is absolutely inspiring that Kai'Sa managed to work through her issues to become the strong, resilient woman we see now, but what I still don't understand is how she managed to do that, presumably on her own. In real life, veteran soldiers struggle with PTSD they experienced from their adult life, and deal with it for years at a time, even decades, even when surrounded by people they love in a safe environment. For me, if Kai'Sa didn't go through a unique and exceptional healing process that allowed her to deal with her own trauma so quickly and so efficiently, I feel it would implicitly devalue or even dismiss the experiences and efforts of these people. As of yet, that part of her story has not been touched upon.

I completely agree that a champion in League is defined not simply by their power, but by their unique personality, and their characteristics that make them truly stand out, even among other legends. To me, Kai'Sa stands out as the most resilient champion in the entire roster: for a person to survive what she went through, and to grow so strong from it, is exceptional. It is because of this that I am so interested in _why_ she is so exceptional, and how that resilience expressed itself since before even her disappearance. Looking through her lore, her VO, her color story, I don't really see that resilience given the attention it deserves, or explained much at all. Perhaps this could be an opportunity for another story, one where we see Kai'Sa at her lowest point and power through to emerge a stronger woman, but this is an essential characteristic of hers, if not her most iconic personality trait: for it to not be made absolutely clear in any of her on-release visuals, VO, bio, color story, or introductory text, I think is a mistake. While I absolutely look forward to the AMA, I feel that if an out-of-game social media event is necessary to properly explain key aspects of a character, then there are critical gaps in that character's presentation.

The apostrophe isn't necessarily meant for a pause when used in a name, it's meant to briefly break the pronunciation of the name by changing the point of enunciation. For example, "Well" and "we'll". The apostrophe in this word stops your tongue on the "we" and starts it anew on the "ll" part of the word to give it a harder delivery, as opposed to the flow of the word "well" as a solid entity. 

Knowing this, there's not really a pause in the names of the Void entities, just changes in enunciation and changes in the emphasis of the parts of the word after the apostrophe. Instead of a flowing "Kaisa" you get "Kai'SA," with the harder "SA" being emphasized.

Picking up on this in particular, because I think the third eye, along with the number three in general, is perhaps one of the most easily recognizable motifs of the Void, yet is conspicuously absent on Kai'Sa. When a Marai dove towards the Void entrance at the bottom of the ocean, he became corrupted enough to grow a third eye in the space of a few weeks. Similarly, Malzahar's exposure to the Void seems to have turned his brain into a Void heart, also giving him the appearance of a third eye. His Voidling minions also have three eyes, and even Vel'Koz has three mini-eyes over his main central one. From what the story says, Kai'Sa spent literal years in the Void entrance, including a significant amount of time with her head and face unprotected, which should have been more than enough to alter her appearance. Giving her a third eye at the very least could have been an easy way to make her appearance much more unnerving, and so in a way that would call back to what we know so far about the Void. Right now, though, her presentation does not lend itself to that at all, and I feel even explicitly aims to make her sexually appealing to the player instead, in stark contrast to how she's meant to come across in the in-game universe.
